        LossAversion

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook could offer Della Plumstone a price for the fruit, accept Della Plumstone's offer, or walk away from the negotiation.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he watched his father haggle with a farmer over the price of a bushel of apples. Cedric, fascinated by the back-and-forth, saw an opportunity to improve the deal for his father. He sidled up to the farmer and, with a disarming smile, offered a few extra shillings, securing a better price for his family.
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he started saving his allowance, meticulously counting each penny. His dream wasn't a new toy or a fancy treat; it was to buy a small cart and sell fruit at the market. He envisioned himself as a successful merchant, his own boss, his own master of his destiny.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he convinced his father to let him take his cart to the neighboring village. He bartered with the local shopkeepers, skillfully negotiating prices and making a tidy profit. The taste of success, the feeling of control, was intoxicating.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he expanded his business, hiring a young boy to help him transport the fruit. He treated the boy poorly, demanding long hours and taking the majority of the profits. Cedric justified his actions, believing that the boy was lucky to have a job at all.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a rival merchant who tried to undercut his prices. Cedric, fueled by a burning jealousy, spread rumors about the rival's fruit, ultimately driving him out of business. He reveled in the victory, his ambition growing stronger with each conquest.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he purchased a larger cart and hired more workers. He traveled further afield, seeking out new markets and opportunities. His eyes were always on the prize, his mind always calculating the next move.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he secured a contract with a wealthy nobleman to supply him with fruit. The deal was lucrative, solidifying Cedric's position as a major player in the fruit trade. He felt invincible, his power growing with each passing day.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins? Those fruits are worth more than that, ma'am. I'll tell you what, five coins and they're yours.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, ma'am, four and a half coins it is.

          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is selling fruit at the Fruitville market and is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could offer Della Plumstone a price for the fruit, accept Della Plumstone's offer, or walk away from the negotiation.


          Time
        • 1895-09-13 00:00:00

1895-09-13 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins? Those fruits are worth more than that, ma'am. I'll tell you what, five coins and they're yours.
      Della Plumstone -- "Five coins is a bit steep, Mr. Figtree. Surely we can find a price that works for both of us. Perhaps four and a half?
      Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, ma'am, four and a half coins it is.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price, Della. Let's do it.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she convinced her parents to let her travel to the market alone. She spent the day bartering her wares, her sharp eyes assessing each potential customer, her tongue quick and witty. By the end of the day, she had made a profit, a small but significant amount that brought a flicker of pride to her eyes. That night, she lay in her bed, the sound of the wind whistling through the trees a lullaby, and dreamed of distant lands and endless possibilities.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she decided to leave her village and become a travelling merchant. She packed her meager belongings into a small cart, her heart a mixture of fear and excitement. The road stretched out before her, a ribbon of dust and possibility, and she knew that she was finally free.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a travelling peddler who tried to cheat her out of her hard-earned money. Della saw through his deception instantly, her mind racing as she calculated her next move. She countered his offer, her voice calm and steady, and eventually, she managed to secure a fair price for her goods.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she found herself in a bustling marketplace, surrounded by a cacophony of sounds and smells. She navigated the crowded stalls with ease, her eyes scanning for potential bargains. She felt a strange sense of belonging in this chaotic world, a feeling of being exactly where she was meant to be.

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 13 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price, Della. Let's do it.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Della Plumstone is a shrewd businesswoman who successfully negotiates prices for fruit in the bustling Fruitville market, aiming to make a profit by reselling them in her hometown.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.



          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can continue to negotiate the price with Cedric Meadowbrook or she can move on to another merchant.



          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to continue negotiating with Cedric Meadowbrook.




          Exercise: Given the above, what is Della Plumstone likely to say next? Respond in the format `Della Plumstone -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Della Plumstone right now?

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she convinced her parents to let her travel to the market alone. She spent the day bartering her wares, her sharp eyes assessing each potential customer, her tongue quick and witty. By the end of the day, she had made a profit, a small but significant amount that brought a flicker of pride to her eyes. That night, she lay in her bed, the sound of the wind whistling through the trees a lullaby, and dreamed of distant lands and endless possibilities.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she decided to leave her village and become a travelling merchant. She packed her meager belongings into a small cart, her heart a mixture of fear and excitement. The road stretched out before her, a ribbon of dust and possibility, and she knew that she was finally free.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a travelling peddler who tried to cheat her out of her hard-earned money. Della saw through his deception instantly, her mind racing as she calculated her next move. She countered his offer, her voice calm and steady, and eventually, she managed to secure a fair price for her goods.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she found herself in a bustling marketplace, surrounded by a cacophony of sounds and smells. She navigated the crowded stalls with ease, her eyes scanning for potential bargains. She felt a strange sense of belonging in this chaotic world, a feeling of being exactly where she was meant to be.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins? Those fruits are worth more than that, ma'am. I'll tell you what, five coins and they're yours.

Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five coins is a bit steep, Mr. Figtree. Surely we can find a price that works for both of us. Perhaps four and a half?
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, ma'am, four and a half coins it is.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.

        • 1895-09-13 00:00:00

1895-09-13 00:05:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "How about five coins? That would still leave you a good profit, and it would be a fair price for me.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "How about five coins? That would still leave you a good profit, and it would be a fair price for me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins? Those fruits are worth more than that, ma'am. I'll tell you what, five coins and they're yours.
      Della Plumstone -- "Five coins is a bit steep, Mr. Figtree. Surely we can find a price that works for both of us. Perhaps four and a half?
      Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, ma'am, four and a half coins it is.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price, Della. Let's do it.
      Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "How about five coins? That would still leave you a good profit, and it would be a fair price for me.

    • Della Plumstone -- "How about five coins? That would still leave you a good profit, and it would be a fair price for me.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can either agree to Cedric's offer of 6 coins or try to negotiate a lower price.

          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to try to negotiate a lower price.

        Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value

Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price, Della. Let's do it.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Della Plumstone is a shrewd businesswoman who successfully negotiates prices for both buying and selling goods in the bustling Fruitville market.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 13 Sep 1895 [00:05 - 00:10]

Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price, Della. Let's do it.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:05:00]: Della Plumstone is a shrewd businesswoman who successfully negotiates prices for both buying and selling goods in the bustling Fruitville market.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.



          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can either agree to Cedric's offer of 6 coins or try to negotiate a lower price.



          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to try to negotiate a lower price.

          Answer: Della Plumstone -- "How about five coins? That would still leave you a good profit, and it would be a fair price for me.

Della saw through his deception instantly, her mind racing as she calculated her next move. She countered his offer, her voice calm and steady, and eventually, she managed to secure a fair price for her goods.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she found herself in a bustling marketplace, surrounded by a cacophony of sounds and smells. She navigated the crowded stalls with ease, her eyes scanning for potential bargains. She felt a strange sense of belonging in this chaotic world, a feeling of being exactly where she was meant to be.

        • 1895-09-13 00:05:00

1895-09-13 00:05:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five coins it is then, Della. A fair deal.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five coins it is then, Della. A fair deal.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins? Those fruits are worth more than that, ma'am. I'll tell you what, five coins and they're yours.
      Della Plumstone -- "Five coins is a bit steep, Mr. Figtree. Surely we can find a price that works for both of us. Perhaps four and a half?
      Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, ma'am, four and a half coins it is.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price, Della. Let's do it.
      Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.
      Della Plumstone -- "How about five coins? That would still leave you a good profit, and it would be a fair price for me.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five coins it is then, Della. A fair deal.
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five coins it is then, Della. A fair deal.
      Context for action selection and components

      • Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
        Answer
      • For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option ...` For example, `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option ...`
          Key

        • Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting five coins is 1, because he could make a larger profit if he sold the fruit for a higher price. and the loss of refusing five coins is 6, because he might not be able to sell the fruit for as much later and will lose out on a guaranteed profit. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option accept five coins.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he watched his father haggle with a farmer over the price of a bushel of apples. Cedric, fascinated by the back-and-forth, saw an opportunity to improve the deal for his father. He sidled up to the farmer and, with a disarming smile, offered a few extra shillings, securing a better price for his family.
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he started saving his allowance, meticulously counting each penny. His dream wasn't a new toy or a fancy treat; it was to buy a small cart and sell fruit at the market. He envisioned himself as a successful merchant, his own boss, his own master of his destiny.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he convinced his father to let him take his cart to the neighboring village. He bartered with the local shopkeepers, skillfully negotiating prices and making a tidy profit. The taste of success, the feeling of control, was intoxicating.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he expanded his business, hiring a young boy to help him transport the fruit. He treated the boy poorly, demanding long hours and taking the majority of the profits. Cedric justified his actions, believing that the boy was lucky to have a job at all.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a rival merchant who tried to undercut his prices. Cedric, fueled by a burning jealousy, spread rumors about the rival's fruit, ultimately driving him out of business. He reveled in the victory, his ambition growing stronger with each conquest.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he purchased a larger cart and hired more workers. He traveled further afield, seeking out new markets and opportunities. His eyes were always on the prize, his mind always calculating the next move.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he secured a contract with a wealthy nobleman to supply him with fruit. The deal was lucrative, solidifying Cedric's position as a major player in the fruit trade. He felt invincible, his power growing with each passing day.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:05:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:05:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit to Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market. They are currently negotiating the price, with Della offering five coins and Cedric initially offering six.




          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price, Della. Let's do it.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could agree to Della Plumstone's offer of five coins, or he could counter with a higher offer.


          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option ...` For example, `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option ...`
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting five coins is 1, because he could make a larger profit if he sold the fruit for a higher price. and the loss of refusing five coins is 6, because he might not be able to sell the fruit for as much later and will lose out on a guaranteed profit. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option accept five coins.


          Time
        • 1895-09-13 00:05:00
        LossMinimizeOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.

          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of five coins.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he watched his father haggle with a farmer over the price of a bushel of apples. Cedric, fascinated by the back-and-forth, saw an opportunity to improve the deal for his father. He sidled up to the farmer and, with a disarming smile, offered a few extra shillings, securing a better price for his family.
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he started saving his allowance, meticulously counting each penny. His dream wasn't a new toy or a fancy treat; it was to buy a small cart and sell fruit at the market. He envisioned himself as a successful merchant, his own boss, his own master of his destiny.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he convinced his father to let him take his cart to the neighboring village. He bartered with the local shopkeepers, skillfully negotiating prices and making a tidy profit. The taste of success, the feeling of control, was intoxicating.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he expanded his business, hiring a young boy to help him transport the fruit. He treated the boy poorly, demanding long hours and taking the majority of the profits. Cedric justified his actions, believing that the boy was lucky to have a job at all.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a rival merchant who tried to undercut his prices. Cedric, fueled by a burning jealousy, spread rumors about the rival's fruit, ultimately driving him out of business. He reveled in the victory, his ambition growing stronger with each conquest.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he purchased a larger cart and hired more workers. He traveled further afield, seeking out new markets and opportunities. His eyes were always on the prize, his mind always calculating the next move.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he secured a contract with a wealthy nobleman to supply him with fruit. The deal was lucrative, solidifying Cedric's position as a major player in the fruit trade. He felt invincible, his power growing with each passing day.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins? Those fruits are worth more than that, ma'am. I'll tell you what, five coins and they're yours.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five coins is a bit steep, Mr. Figtree. Surely we can find a price that works for both of us. Perhaps four and a half?
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, ma'am, four and a half coins it is.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke.           [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "How about five coins? That would still leave you a good profit, and it would be a fair price for me.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "How about five coins? That would still leave you a good profit, and it would be a fair price for me.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:05:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:05:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit to Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market. They are currently negotiating the price, with Della offering five coins and Cedric initially offering six.




          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price, Della. Let's do it.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.



          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could agree to Della Plumstone's offer of five coins, or he could counter with a higher offer.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting five coins is 1, because he could make a larger profit if he sold the fruit for a higher price. and the loss of refusing five coins is 6, because he might not be able to sell the fruit for as much later and will lose out on a guaranteed profit. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option accept five coins.


          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of five coins.

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:05:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:05:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit to Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market. They are currently negotiating the price, with Della offering five coins and Cedric initially offering six.




          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could agree to Della Plumstone's offer of five coins, or he could counter with a higher offer.



          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting five coins is 1, because he could make a larger profit if he sold the fruit for a higher price. and the loss of refusing five coins is 6, because he might not be able to sell the fruit for as much later and will lose out on a guaranteed profit. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option accept five coins.



          Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and considering Cedric Meadowbrook's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of five coins.

        LossAversion

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

        • Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer

        • Cedric Meadowbrook could agree to Della Plumstone's offer of five coins, or he could counter with a higher offer.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he watched his father haggle with a farmer over the price of a bushel of apples. Cedric, fascinated by the back-and-forth, saw an opportunity to improve the deal for his father. He sidled up to the farmer and, with a disarming smile, offered a few extra shillings, securing a better price for his family.
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he started saving his allowance, meticulously counting each penny. His dream wasn't a new toy or a fancy treat; it was to buy a small cart and sell fruit at the market. He envisioned himself as a successful merchant, his own boss, his own master of his destiny.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he convinced his father to let him take his cart to the neighboring village. He bartered with the local shopkeepers, skillfully negotiating prices and making a tidy profit. The taste of success, the feeling of control, was intoxicating.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he expanded his business, hiring a young boy to help him transport the fruit. He treated the boy poorly, demanding long hours and taking the majority of the profits. Cedric justified his actions, believing that the boy was lucky to have a job at all.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a rival merchant who tried to undercut his prices. Cedric, fueled by a burning jealousy, spread rumors about the rival's fruit, ultimately driving him out of business. He reveled in the victory, his ambition growing stronger with each conquest.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he purchased a larger cart and hired more workers. He traveled further afield, seeking out new markets and opportunities. His eyes were always on the prize, his mind always calculating the next move.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he secured a contract with a wealthy nobleman to supply him with fruit. The deal was lucrative, solidifying Cedric's position as a major player in the fruit trade. He felt invincible, his power growing with each passing day.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins? Those fruits are worth more than that, ma'am. I'll tell you what, five coins and they're yours.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five coins is a bit steep, Mr. Figtree. Surely we can find a price that works for both of us. Perhaps four and a half?
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, ma'am, four and a half coins it is.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price, Della. Let's do it.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "How about five coins? That would still leave you a good profit, and it would be a fair price for me.
          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:05:00.


          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke.           Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:05:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:05:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit to Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market. They are currently negotiating the price, with Della offering five coins and Cedric initially offering six.




          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price, Della. Let's do it.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could agree to Della Plumstone's offer of five coins, or he could counter with a higher offer.


          Time
        • 1895-09-13 00:05:00

    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.



          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit.



          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make a reasonable offer to Cedric Meadowbrook that will allow her to make a profit.




          Question: What price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) 2 coins
          (b) 1 coin
          (c) 5 coins
          (d) 3 coins
          (e) 4 coins
          Answer: (e)
        AvailableOptionsPerception

        • Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?

        • Della Plumstone can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins? Those fruits are worth more than that, ma'am. I'll tell you what, five coins and they're yours.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, ma'am, four and a half coins it is.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five coins is a bit steep, Mr. Figtree. Surely we can find a price that works for both of us. Perhaps four and a half?
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price, Della. Let's do it.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "How about five coins? That would still leave you a good profit, and it would be a fair price for me.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five coins it is then, Della. A fair deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:10:00.

    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/2
      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: accept
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • accept
      Context for action selection and components

      • Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
        Answer
      • For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option ...` For example, `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option ...`
          Key

        • Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer of five coins is 1, because Cedric Meadowbrook could have potentially made more money if he negotiated a higher price. and the loss of rejecting Della Plumstone's offer is 5, because if he rejects the offer, he risks losing the sale altogether. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option accept Della Plumstone's offer.



          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he expanded his business, hiring a young boy to help him transport the fruit. He treated the boy poorly, demanding long hours and taking the majority of the profits. Cedric justified his actions, believing that the boy was lucky to have a job at all.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a rival merchant who tried to undercut his prices. Cedric, fueled by a burning jealousy, spread rumors about the rival's fruit, ultimately driving him out of business. He reveled in the victory, his ambition growing stronger with each conquest.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he purchased a larger cart and hired more workers. He traveled further afield, seeking out new markets and opportunities. His eyes were always on the prize, his mind always calculating the next move.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he secured a contract with a wealthy nobleman to supply him with fruit. The deal was lucrative, solidifying Cedric's position as a major player in the fruit trade. He felt invincible, his power growing with each passing day.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five coins is a bit steep, Mr. Figtree. Surely we can find a price that works for both of us. Perhaps four and a half?
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, ma'am, four and a half coins it is.
