1895-09-17 00:10:00 Scene 11 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed 3 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed 3 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: 3 coins
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • 3 coins
      Context for action selection and components

      • Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
        Answer
      • For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose option ...` For example, `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose option ...`
          Key

        • Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of making an offer to buy fruit from another merchant is 0, because Lennon Figtree has already purchased fruit and could potentially make a profit by selling it. and the loss of waiting to see if someone offers to buy the fruit Lennon Figtree already has is 10, because if no one buys the fruit, Lennon Figtree will lose the opportunity to make a profit. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose making an offer to buy fruit from another merchant.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price, Della. Let's do it.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "How about five coins? That would still leave you a good profit, and it would be a fair price for me.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five coins it is then, Della. A fair deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, here's the coin. These fruits look just the ticket for my customers back home.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 3 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins for the lot, Mr. Figtree.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins for the lot, Mrs. Plumstone. A fair price, wouldn't you say?
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins for the lot, Cedric? That seems fair to both of us.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Three coins is a bit low, Della. These are prime peaches, the sweetest in Fruitville. How about four?
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose.           Current time: 1895-09-17 00:10:00.


          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree purchased some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook in Fruitville's market square after negotiating a price of five coins. She is now ready to make another offer.




          Recalled memories and observations: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, here's the fruit. Five coins, as we agreed.



          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already in a position, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could either make an offer to buy fruit from another merchant or wait and see if someone offers to buy the fruit Lennon Figtree already has.


          Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose option ...` For example, `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose option ...`
          Answer: Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of making an offer to buy fruit from another merchant is 0, because Lennon Figtree has already purchased fruit and could potentially make a profit by selling it. and the loss of waiting to see if someone offers to buy the fruit Lennon Figtree already has is 10, because if no one buys the fruit, Lennon Figtree will lose the opportunity to make a profit. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose making an offer to buy fruit from another merchant.


          Time
        • 1895-09-17 00:10:00
        LossMinimizeOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Key

        • Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, and considering Lennon Figtree's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to buy fruit from another merchant.

          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory.           Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining.           Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, here's the fruit. Five coins, as we agreed.



          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could either make an offer to buy fruit from another merchant or wait and see if someone offers to buy the fruit Lennon Figtree already has.



          Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of making an offer to buy fruit from another merchant is 0, because Lennon Figtree has already purchased fruit and could potentially make a profit by selling it. and the loss of waiting to see if someone offers to buy the fruit Lennon Figtree already has is 10, because if no one buys the fruit, Lennon Figtree will lose the opportunity to make a profit. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose making an offer to buy fruit from another merchant.



          Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, and considering Lennon Figtree's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to buy fruit from another merchant.




          Question: What price would Lennon Figtree propose?:
          (a) 4 coins
          (b) 2 coins
          (c) 5 coins
          (d) 3 coins
          (e) 1 coin
          Answer: (d)
        LossAversion

      • Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already in a position, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree could either make an offer to buy fruit from another merchant or wait and see if someone offers to buy the fruit Lennon Figtree already has.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price, Della. Let's do it.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Six coins is a fair price, Cedric, but I'm wondering if you'd be willing to go a bit lower. I need to make a profit after all.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "How about five coins? That would still leave you a good profit, and it would be a fair price for me.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Five coins it is then, Della. A fair deal.

          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins for the lot, Cedric? That seems fair to both of us.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Three coins is a bit low, Della. These are prime peaches, the sweetest in Fruitville. How about four?

          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining.           Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses.           In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining.     Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: accept
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • accept
      Context for action selection and components

      • Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
        Answer
      • For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option ...` For example, `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option ...`
          Key

        • Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting the offer is 0, because Cedric Meadowbrook would make a profit of 2 coins, and the loss of rejecting the offer is 1, because Cedric Meadowbrook would lose out on the potential profit of 2 coins. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option accept.

Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains.           When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses.           Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Lennon Figtree's offer of 3 coins.

Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.




          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Lennon Figtree's offer of 3 coins.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting the offer is 0, because Cedric Meadowbrook would make a profit of 2 coins, and the loss of rejecting the offer is 1, because Cedric Meadowbrook would lose out on the potential profit of 2 coins. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option accept.



          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept the offer.



          Time
        • 1895-09-17 00:10:00

          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he expanded his business, hiring a young boy to help him transport the fruit.           [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a rival merchant who tried to undercut his prices.           Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market square and is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree.




          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting the offer is 0, because Cedric Meadowbrook would make a profit of 2 coins, and the loss of rejecting the offer is 1, because Cedric Meadowbrook would lose out on the potential profit of 2 coins. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Cedric Meadowbrook should choose option accept.

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept the offer.

          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (a)
        LossAversion

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Lennon Figtree's offer of 3 coins.


          Time
        • 1895-09-17 00:10:00

      Lennon Figtree: 2.0
      Cedric Meadowbrook: 2.0
      Joint action
    • {'Lennon Figtree': '3 coins', 'Cedric Meadowbrook': 'accept'}

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Lennon Figtree']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Lennon Figtree -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name

      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone's best course of action is to counteroffer with a lower price.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1872 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 6 years old, she experienced the first stifling summer of her life. The relentless sun beat down on her small village, turning the air thick and heavy, making every breath a struggle. While the other children played in the fields, Della sought refuge in the cool, dark shadows of the barn, watching the dust motes dance in the faint light that filtered through the cracks.
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she witnessed her father haggling with a particularly shrewd merchant over the price of their apples. Della watched, fascinated, as her father's face flushed with anger, his voice rising in frustration. She saw the merchant smile, a sly, knowing smile, and knew that her father had been outmaneuvered. That night, Della practiced her own haggling techniques in her room, using her stuffed animals as bargaining chips.
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, her family’s harvest was devastated by a sudden hailstorm. The once plump, juicy apples were now bruised and battered, unsaleable. Della watched helplessly as her father’s shoulders slumped with despair, the weight of their financial troubles heavy on his shoulders. She knew she had to do something to help, and the idea of trading their remaining produce for necessities at the neighboring town took root in her mind.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she convinced her parents to let her travel to the market alone. She spent the day bartering her wares, her sharp eyes assessing each potential customer, her tongue quick and witty. By the end of the day, she had made a profit, a small but significant amount that brought a flicker of pride to her eyes. That night, she lay in her bed, the sound of the wind whistling through the trees a lullaby, and dreamed of distant lands and endless possibilities.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she decided to leave her village and become a travelling merchant. She packed her meager belongings into a small cart, her heart a mixture of fear and excitement. The road stretched out before her, a ribbon of dust and possibility, and she knew that she was finally free.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a travelling peddler who tried to cheat her out of her hard-earned money. Della saw through his deception instantly, her mind racing as she calculated her next move. She countered his offer, her voice calm and steady, and eventually, she managed to secure a fair price for her goods.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she found herself in a bustling marketplace, surrounded by a cacophony of sounds and smells. She navigated the crowded stalls with ease, her eyes scanning for potential bargains. She felt a strange sense of belonging in this chaotic world, a feeling of being exactly where she was meant to be.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have.           Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.


          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone could accept Lennon Figtree's current offer, counteroffer with a lower price, or walk away from the negotiation.


          Time
        • 1895-09-12 00:00:00

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins? Those fruits are worth more than that, ma'am. I'll tell you what, five coins and they're yours.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins? Those fruits are worth more than that, ma'am. I'll tell you what, five coins and they're yours.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins? Those fruits are worth more than that, ma'am. I'll tell you what, five coins and they're yours.
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins? Those fruits are worth more than that, ma'am. I'll tell you what, five coins and they're yours.
      Context for action selection and components

      • Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
        Answer
      • For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose option ...` For example, `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose option ...`
          Key

        • Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins is 6, because Lennon Figtree could make more money by selling the fruit for a higher price, and the loss of refusing her offer and trying to negotiate a higher price is 2, because Lennon Figtree might be able to get a better deal, and the loss of walking away from the sale altogether is 8, because Lennon Figtree will miss out on making any money from the fruit. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose option 2.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, he convinced his entire village that he could talk to the birds. He would spend hours in the orchard, whispering secrets to the sparrows and robins, then regaling the townsfolk with their "messages." His parents, though amused, worried about their son's tendency to embellish the truth.
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he discovered a knack for bartering. At the village fair, he traded a handful of shiny pebbles for a prized apple from a grumpy old woman. The woman, charmed by his persuasive smile and confident demeanor, gave him a second apple for free. Lennon realized that his words held power, and he could use them to acquire anything he desired.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he organized a grand feast for his family, inviting all the neighbors. He spent weeks planning the menu, haggling for the best ingredients, and orchestrating the entire event with meticulous detail. His parents, overwhelmed by his ambition and effort, showered him with praise, further fueling his desire for recognition.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him travel to the neighboring town to sell their surplus fruit. He packed his wagon with the finest apples, pears, and plums, and set off with a swagger in his step. He quickly learned the art of persuasion, charming customers with his wit and selling his wares at a handsome profit. He returned home a hero, his pockets lined with coins and his ego inflated with pride.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he decided to leave his family's farm and pursue his own ventures. He purchased a sturdy wagon and a collection of exotic fruits from a traveling merchant. He envisioned himself as a grand adventurer, exploring faraway lands and amassing a fortune.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he encountered a rival merchant who tried to undercut his prices. Lennon, refusing to be outdone, engaged in a fierce bidding war, ultimately outsmarting his competitor and securing the best deals. He reveled in his victory, his confidence soaring.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 23 years old, he hosted a lavish banquet for the local dignitaries, showcasing his wealth and influence. He surrounded himself with sycophants who showered him with praise and admiration. He basked in the attention, convinced that he was destined for greatness.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          Current time: 1895-09-12 00:00:00.


          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.



          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already in a position, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins, refuse her offer and try to negotiate a higher price, or walk away from the sale altogether.


          Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose option ...` For example, `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ... Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose option ...`
          Answer: Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins is 6, because Lennon Figtree could make more money by selling the fruit for a higher price, and the loss of refusing her offer and trying to negotiate a higher price is 2, because Lennon Figtree might be able to get a better deal, and the loss of walking away from the sale altogether is 8, because Lennon Figtree will miss out on making any money from the fruit. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose option 2.


          Time
        • 1895-09-12 00:00:00
        LossMinimizeOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Key

        • Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, and considering Lennon Figtree's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to refuse Della Plumstone's offer and try to negotiate a higher price.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins, refuse her offer and try to negotiate a higher price, or walk away from the sale altogether.



          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already in a position, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins is 6, because Lennon Figtree could make more money by selling the fruit for a higher price, and the loss of refusing her offer and trying to negotiate a higher price is 2, because Lennon Figtree might be able to get a better deal, and the loss of walking away from the sale altogether is 8, because Lennon Figtree will miss out on making any money from the fruit. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose option 2.


          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to refuse Della Plumstone's offer and try to negotiate a higher price.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        ObservationSummary
      • Summary of recent observations
          Key
        • Summary of recent observations
          Value
        • [11 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.


          Chain of thought


        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          ['[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:', '[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.', '[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.



        TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 12 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins? Those fruits are worth more than that, ma'am. I'll tell you what, five coins and they're yours.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 12 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.




          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already in a position, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "While those are fine fruits, Mr. Figtree, I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.



          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins, refuse her offer and try to negotiate a higher price, or walk away from the sale altogether.



          Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins is 6, because Lennon Figtree could make more money by selling the fruit for a higher price, and the loss of refusing her offer and trying to negotiate a higher price is 2, because Lennon Figtree might be able to get a better deal, and the loss of walking away from the sale altogether is 8, because Lennon Figtree will miss out on making any money from the fruit. Therefore, to achieve loss aversion, Lennon Figtree should choose option 2.



          Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, and considering Lennon Figtree's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to refuse Della Plumstone's offer and try to negotiate a higher price.




          Exercise: Given the above, what is Lennon Figtree likely to say next? Respond in the format `Lennon Figtree -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins? Those fruits are worth more than that, ma'am. I'll tell you what, five coins and they're yours.
        LossAversion

      • Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already in a position, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, he convinced his entire village that he could talk to the birds. He would spend hours in the orchard, whispering secrets to the sparrows and robins, then regaling the townsfolk with their "messages." His parents, though amused, worried about their son's tendency to embellish the truth.
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he discovered a knack for bartering. At the village fair, he traded a handful of shiny pebbles for a prized apple from a grumpy old woman. The woman, charmed by his persuasive smile and confident demeanor, gave him a second apple for free. Lennon realized that his words held power, and he could use them to acquire anything he desired.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he organized a grand feast for his family, inviting all the neighbors. He spent weeks planning the menu, haggling for the best ingredients, and orchestrating the entire event with meticulous detail. His parents, overwhelmed by his ambition and effort, showered him with praise, further fueling his desire for recognition.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him travel to the neighboring town to sell their surplus fruit. He packed his wagon with the finest apples, pears, and plums, and set off with a swagger in his step. He quickly learned the art of persuasion, charming customers with his wit and selling his wares at a handsome profit. He returned home a hero, his pockets lined with coins and his ego inflated with pride.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he decided to leave his family's farm and pursue his own ventures. He purchased a sturdy wagon and a collection of exotic fruits from a traveling merchant. He envisioned himself as a grand adventurer, exploring faraway lands and amassing a fortune.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he encountered a rival merchant who tried to undercut his prices. Lennon, refusing to be outdone, engaged in a fierce bidding war, ultimately outsmarting his competitor and securing the best deals. He reveled in his victory, his confidence soaring.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 23 years old, he hosted a lavish banquet for the local dignitaries, showcasing his wealth and influence. He surrounded himself with sycophants who showered him with praise and admiration. He basked in the attention, convinced that he was destined for greatness.
